HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 4, 1926.

DR. GREENLAW
DR. MUSTARD PRESIDENT
OF TUDOR=STUART CLUB
As a result of the elections
held in the business meeting
of the Tudor and Stuart Club
last Friday night the Board
of Governors for next year
will be as follows: Dr. Wilfred P. Mustard, President;
Dr. Edwin Greenlaw, VicePresident; Dr. Carol Van
Buren Wight, Cura tor; Arnold
Waters, SecretaryTreasurer; Dr. John C.
French, Ernest Strathman,
Brinton Stone, and Charles
Dorsey, members of the
Board.
With the conclusion of the
regular business of the club,
Dr. M. L. Raney, retiring
president, introduced Dr.
Samuel W. Lambert of New
York, who gave a talk on
Izaak Walton and exhibited
some of his rare first editions of The Complete Angler.

In spite of some of the poorest
officiating seen in years and a field
that is far from the standard set
by our own, the Blue Jay -sharpshooters" managed to score six
goals against Swarthmore and to
defeat one of the Garnet's best
teams, 6-1.

and looked like anyone's game for
the first few minutes. Hopkins'

SPEAKS ON

STUDENTS' CHOICE
OF STUDIES
Attitudes In Selecting Subjects
Enumerated By Lectures
At Assembly

-What a student's attitude
ough to be toward his choice of
studies," was the subject of an
address by Dr. Greenlaw at the
assembly last week.
-There are various ways of approach," said Dr. Greenlaw. "One
is what I shall call the invalid
view. According to this view,
studies are a sort of medicine
taken to cure invalids. The study
considered the most valuable is
the one you are most likely to forget. Latin and Greek, therefore,
are classed among the highest type
because they may b\e, forgotten a
few minutes after leaving the
class-room.

Friday Night; Sophs Fail Last Night
FRESHMEN BANQUET
IS HELD OA BOAT
Having failed to break up
the sophomore banquet Friday night, the freshmen class
determined to keep the sophs
from its own, and succeeded
admirably. For, at 6:45 last
night, two hundred frosh
boarded the good ship Annapolis and sailed down the
Chesapeake Bay, dining as
they went.
The sophomores, foiled in
their attempt to find the banquet until it was too late,
took revenge on' freshman
automobiles parked in the
vicinity of the wharf.
Four captured sophs and
a jazz band supplied the entertainment. Evans Rodgers
sang and danced, while Talbott, Coney, and Wagner.
all '28 men, enhanced the
atmosphere of triumph that
pervaded the banquet.

Starting fifteen minutes after
the junior banquet, the sophomore
class retired to Workman's Hall,
East I3altimore,'Friday, night and
held its own feast, unmolested by
freshmen or other undesirables.
The banquet itself was hardly a
fitting climax to the antics of the
two underclasses during the day,
however. Three arrests, five or
six captures, and an automobil
accident were only a few of tL
thrillers on the day's menu. Ti
entire campus was pervaded with
an air of. anticipation as the eligible date of the banquet drew
near.

We could never understand that belligerent, war-like attitude the ordinary scholar assumes as soon as he becomes a
professor. Perhaps it is the lighting instinct with which we
are credited, perhaps the instinct of fear. But whatever the
cause, we do know- there is a battle going on, a struggle between teacher and student.
It is really absorbing to watch this ludricous and pathetic
struggle. The professor spews out his crazily compounded
lectures fol., say two weeks. The enemy stores these effusions
in a little notebook, only to throw them back when the next attack, a quiz, comes. If a lone student attempts to make a
single-handed assault in verbal controversy by tiring a question,
he finds himself on untenable ground, between two fires. For,
according to the rules of modern warfare, laid down by the
teacher, this is a violation of all the laws that were ever written. And on the other hand, what re-enforcement does the
courageous one get from his allies? They respond joyfully
with their moral support by yelling, -Handshaker, handshaker."
But the battle still rages, and at the end of two weeks a
violent skirmish is begun.
,
And those skirmishes, those quizzes. For some time after
the beginning of the yearly hostilities the professor endeavors
to outguess the student-enemy as to the time of skirmish. Now
it is on Tuesday, now on Wednesday, now on ,Friday. To what
purpose? But that's all in the game. Suppose the enemy can't
guess? Hard luck! The professor puts it down for another
casualty. Just the rightful spoils of war. Besides, everything
is fair in love and war. And this is war!
Just how shrewd the student becomes, or is forced to become in order to survive. It is sink or swim. .Soon after the
beginning of the year he guesses almost precisely when the
enemy's attack will come. Ile can tell to a day, or at least
within two days. If he does not get it on Tuesday it will surely
be on Friday ; and so he will prepare all the harder to beat the
'teacher.
And what does the teacher do when he discovers that he is
being outguessed, for he surely will, being a good officer, assume the student has as much innate feeling for war as he has?
He proceeds to devise new methods of attack.
And what is this new attack? This time, being foiled in
the surprise attack, the professor immediately proceeds to
locate some of the most obscure and out-of-the-way points where
he call attack from the flank, and where he knows the enemy to
be weakest. Those questions! Those hellish things could be
fashioned only by a Hindoo mystic or a bow-legged saxophone
player.
When does the war end? There is no end, only a truce.
There is a helluva battle that continues for about a week at the
end of May. In this battle, which is recognized, and generally
compelled by official regulations, all the teachers unite, and
each take one final crack. This always finishes the enemy,
intellectually as far as the course goes, if he passes, and financially if Ite doesn't. -At the end of this big battle hostilities are
over for that term, to begin again the following October.
Perhaps our ideas on college are wrong and childish. Perhaps our feelings are too pacifistic when we believe there should
be an alliance between student and teacher; an association in
which there are no war-like methods, no guesswork, no struggle.
Undoubtedly we must be wrong, for it must be much better
to have deception, and battles and struggles, instead of a peaceful league for the pursuit of knowledge.
And yet, what did Sherman say?

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 4, 1926.

THE HIGHEST TEST
We see in the columns of this issue that each senior has
;pledged himself to give one hundred dollars to the University
din the next ten years. This seems to us one of the most convincing proofs of college loyalty that has been manifested for a
- long time.
i[
In former years, when there was not the slightest hint
that the present order of things would be shaken, graduating
classes have pledged money to the University, usually with the
:33tipulation that it be used for the advancement of some phase
:pcof undergraduate life. It was only natural for them to make
this reservation in favor of the side of college life that they
!knew best, and which had meant so much to them.
It has rerimined for the class of '26 to show how deep the
loyalty of the undergraduates really is. We do not believe that
,the majority of them are in favor of the new plan from a
;purely personal point of view. The traditions and institutions
• under whose influence they have come, and which in turn they
have helped to develop will in all probability be greatly modified, if not entirely done away with.
Members of the senior class have probably been influenced
by these points, but they have had the vision to see beyond them.
After all, Hopkins, whether it clings to the old order of things,
or whether it strikes out into new and untried fields, remains
their university, and to it, whatever course it may follow,
t hey have made their pledges unreservedly.

D. N. G.
S. S. K.

T

JUNE WEEK
The one fact that- makes-44w- final exatnimations --different
from the mid-year atrocities, and about the only thing that
can be said in their favor is that they are followed by June
Week, which according to leading campus authorities, is more
than enough to offset the minor inconveniences of intensive
study.
The June Week Committee's able and active press agents
have been doing their work so well, that there is little need for
us to offer any eiplanation of the event, or to list the indisputable reasons why everyone should attend. To more facile
pens and more fervid imaginations we leave the glowing descriptions of the last chance for fellowship with the comrades of
four years, dreamy music in the Botanical Gardens, mellow
moonlight and the one and only girl—provided, of course, that
,she isn't with somebodyelse--at the time and all the rest.
We merely wish to suggest to those who have not had the
'pleasure of attending a June Week that they make every effort
to do so this year. It will be well worth while. The social side
of college life has never been especially emphasized at Hopkins.
There are, of course, the weekly informal dances, and the two
,cotillions, but the only important attempt along those lines is
June Week. Coming after the long grind, and marked by the
return of many of the younger alumni, it presents a wonderful
opportunity for a few days of that close comradeship of which
Hopkins, for a small college, has all too little.
This year's committee has worked hard and has worked
well. The NEWS-LETTER wishes them all the success they deserve.

Each Senior Will
Give University $100

FITCH'S "THE TRUTH" WILL
BE PRESENTED BY

At a recent meeting of the senior
class it was moved and passed that
each member of the Class of 1926
should make a present of $100 to
the University, payable within 10
years after graduation.
The Junior Class meeting held
last Friday was entirely given up
to discussion of the banquet that
night.

Attitudes In Selecting Subjects
Enumerated By Lectures
At Assembly

-What a student's attitude
ough to be toward his choice of
studies," was the subject of an
address by Dr. Greenlaw at the
assembly last week.
-There are various ways of approach," said Dr. Greenlaw. "One
is what I shall call the invalid
view. According to this view,
studies are a sort of medicine
taken to cure invalids. The study
considered the most valuable is
the one you are most likely to forget. Latin and Greek, therefore,
are classed among the highest type
because they may b\e, forgotten a
few minutes after leaving the
class-room.

We could never understand that belligerent, war-like attitude the ordinary scholar assumes as soon as he becomes a
professor. Perhaps it is the lighting instinct with which we
are credited, perhaps the instinct of fear. But whatever the
cause, we do know- there is a battle going on, a struggle between teacher and student.
It is really absorbing to watch this ludricous and pathetic
struggle. The professor spews out his crazily compounded
lectures fol., say two weeks. The enemy stores these effusions
in a little notebook, only to throw them back when the next attack, a quiz, comes. If a lone student attempts to make a
single-handed assault in verbal controversy by tiring a question,
he finds himself on untenable ground, between two fires. For,
according to the rules of modern warfare, laid down by the
teacher, this is a violation of all the laws that were ever written. And on the other hand, what re-enforcement does the
courageous one get from his allies? They respond joyfully
with their moral support by yelling, -Handshaker, handshaker."
But the battle still rages, and at the end of two weeks a
violent skirmish is begun.
,
And those skirmishes, those quizzes. For some time after
the beginning of the yearly hostilities the professor endeavors
to outguess the student-enemy as to the time of skirmish. Now
it is on Tuesday, now on Wednesday, now on ,Friday. To what
purpose? But that's all in the game. Suppose the enemy can't
guess? Hard luck! The professor puts it down for another
casualty. Just the rightful spoils of war. Besides, everything
is fair in love and war. And this is war!
Just how shrewd the student becomes, or is forced to become in order to survive. It is sink or swim. .Soon after the
beginning of the year he guesses almost precisely when the
enemy's attack will come. Ile can tell to a day, or at least
within two days. If he does not get it on Tuesday it will surely
be on Friday ; and so he will prepare all the harder to beat the
'teacher.
And what does the teacher do when he discovers that he is
being outguessed, for he surely will, being a good officer, assume the student has as much innate feeling for war as he has?
He proceeds to devise new methods of attack.
And what is this new attack? This time, being foiled in
the surprise attack, the professor immediately proceeds to
locate some of the most obscure and out-of-the-way points where
he call attack from the flank, and where he knows the enemy to
be weakest. Those questions! Those hellish things could be
fashioned only by a Hindoo mystic or a bow-legged saxophone
player.
When does the war end? There is no end, only a truce.
There is a helluva battle that continues for about a week at the
end of May. In this battle, which is recognized, and generally
compelled by official regulations, all the teachers unite, and
each take one final crack. This always finishes the enemy,
intellectually as far as the course goes, if he passes, and financially if Ite doesn't. -At the end of this big battle hostilities are
over for that term, to begin again the following October.
Perhaps our ideas on college are wrong and childish. Perhaps our feelings are too pacifistic when we believe there should
be an alliance between student and teacher; an association in
which there are no war-like methods, no guesswork, no struggle.
Undoubtedly we must be wrong, for it must be much better
to have deception, and battles and struggles, instead of a peaceful league for the pursuit of knowledge.
And yet, what did Sherman say?

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 4, 1926.

THE HIGHEST TEST
We see in the columns of this issue that each senior has
;pledged himself to give one hundred dollars to the University
din the next ten years. This seems to us one of the most convincing proofs of college loyalty that has been manifested for a
- long time.
i[
In former years, when there was not the slightest hint
that the present order of things would be shaken, graduating
classes have pledged money to the University, usually with the
:33tipulation that it be used for the advancement of some phase
:pcof undergraduate life. It was only natural for them to make
this reservation in favor of the side of college life that they
!knew best, and which had meant so much to them.
It has rerimined for the class of '26 to show how deep the
loyalty of the undergraduates really is. We do not believe that
,the majority of them are in favor of the new plan from a
;purely personal point of view. The traditions and institutions
• under whose influence they have come, and which in turn they
have helped to develop will in all probability be greatly modified, if not entirely done away with.
Members of the senior class have probably been influenced
by these points, but they have had the vision to see beyond them.
After all, Hopkins, whether it clings to the old order of things,
or whether it strikes out into new and untried fields, remains
their university, and to it, whatever course it may follow,
t hey have made their pledges unreservedly.

D. N. G.
S. S. K.

T

JUNE WEEK
The one fact that- makes-44w- final exatnimations --different
from the mid-year atrocities, and about the only thing that
can be said in their favor is that they are followed by June
Week, which according to leading campus authorities, is more
than enough to offset the minor inconveniences of intensive
study.
The June Week Committee's able and active press agents
have been doing their work so well, that there is little need for
us to offer any eiplanation of the event, or to list the indisputable reasons why everyone should attend. To more facile
pens and more fervid imaginations we leave the glowing descriptions of the last chance for fellowship with the comrades of
four years, dreamy music in the Botanical Gardens, mellow
moonlight and the one and only girl—provided, of course, that
,she isn't with somebodyelse--at the time and all the rest.
We merely wish to suggest to those who have not had the
'pleasure of attending a June Week that they make every effort
to do so this year. It will be well worth while. The social side
of college life has never been especially emphasized at Hopkins.
There are, of course, the weekly informal dances, and the two
,cotillions, but the only important attempt along those lines is
June Week. Coming after the long grind, and marked by the
return of many of the younger alumni, it presents a wonderful
opportunity for a few days of that close comradeship of which
Hopkins, for a small college, has all too little.
This year's committee has worked hard and has worked
well. The NEWS-LETTER wishes them all the success they deserve.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS- NEWS-LETTER; MAY 4, 1926.

Each Senior Will
Give University $100

FITCH'S "THE TRUTH" WILL
BE PRESENTED BY

At a recent meeting of the senior
class it was moved and passed that
each member of the Class of 1926
should make a present of $100 to
the University, payable within 10
years after graduation.
The Junior Class meeting held
last Friday was entirely given up
to discussion of the banquet that
night.
